metadata.titleEn: QTP-NDVI30: High spatiotemporal resolution (30-m and 8-d) NDVI time-series data during 2000-2020 for the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau
metadata.description:
Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) has been widely used for monitoring vegetation. This dataset employed all available Landsat 5/7/8 data on the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau (QTP) (> 100,000 scenes), and reconstructed high spatiotemporal NDVI time-series data (30-m and 8-d) during 2000-2020 on the TP (QTP-NDVI30) by using the MODIS-Landsat fusion algorithm (gap filling and Savitzky–Golay filtering；GF-SG). For the details of GF-SG, please refer to Chen et al. (2021).
This dataset has been evaluated carefully. The quantitative assessments show that the reconstructed NDVI images have an average MAE value of 0.02, correlation coefficient of 0.96, and SSIM value of 0.94. We compared the reconstructed images in some typical areas with the PlanetScope 3-m images and found that the spatial details were well preserved by QTP-NDVI30.
The geographic coordinate system of this dataset is GCS_WGS_84. The spatial range covers the vegetation area of the QTP, which is defined as the areas with average NDVI during July- September larger than 0.15.
metadata.instructions:
-The data of the same year was stored in the same folder, and the folder was named QTP_NDVI_XXXX(Year). The data were named by QTP_NDVI_XXXX(Year)_XX(Index).tiff, and the Index order corresponds to the date of the MOD09Q1 time series data of the current year.The data were in .tiff format, which can be read by software such as ENVI and ArcGIS. The NDVI time-series data in 2012 were not reconstructed due to the failure of Landsat 5. We will update the data after 2020 in the future.
For the use of this dataset,  please refer to the following citations:

“The QTP-NDVI30 dataset (8-day and 30-m spatiotemporal resolution) was collected from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center (TPDC) (Cao et al., 2022a). This dataset was generated through the fusion of MODIS (250 m) and Landsat (30 m) NDVI time-series data using the Gap Filling and Savitzky–Golay (GF-SG) fusion method (Chen et al., 2021), and showed satisfactory accuracy with visual inspection and quantitative assessments (Cao et al., 2022b)”.

background: As the largest and highest alpine ecoregion in the world, the Qinghai–Tibetan Plateau (QTP) is extremely sensitive to climate change and has experienced extraordinary warming during the past several decades; this has greatly affected various ecosystem processes in this region such as vegetation production and phenological change. The Qinghai–Tibetan Plateau (QTP), known as the third pole of the world, is the largest and highest alpine ecoregion. During the past few decades, the QTP has experienced rapid climate warming, with a rate of temperature increase two times the global average. The satellite-derived normalized-difference vegetation index (NDVI) is the most commonly used indicator for monitoring vegetation dynamics. Compared with other land-cover types, green vegetation displays higher reflectance in the near-infrared wavelength and lower reflectance in the red wavelength; thus, NDVI combines reflectance in the two wavelengths in a normalized form to enhance the contrast between green vegetation and other land-cover types. The continuous GIMMS NDVI and MODIS NDVI time-series data provide useful information to characterize intraseasonal greenness changes; however, the coarse pixel sizes (~8 km for GIMMS and 250 m for MODIS) impede vegetation monitoring in topographic regions.
research objective: In this study, therefore, we generated an 8-day and 30 m resolution NDVI dataset from 2000 to 2020 for the QTP through the fusion of 30 m Landsat and 250 m MODIS NDVI time-series data. In this study, we reconstructed high-spatiotemporal-resolution NDVI time-series data (30 m and 8 days) from 2000–2020 for the QTP through the fusion of 30 m Landsat and 250 m MODIS NDVI time-series with the GF-SG method.
challenges: However, the highest spatial resolution of only 250 m for the MODIS NDVI product cannot meet the requirement of vegetation monitoring in heterogeneous topographic areas. The area of the QTP is nearly 2.5 million km2; thus, reconstructing high-quality continuous Landsat NDVI time-series data for the entire QTP is a challenging objective; this is due to the vast amounts of Landsat imagery and data required for analyses, which cannot be obtained by most of the previous reconstruction methods. NDVI reconstruction in large areas may present various difficulties. For example, cloud removal on Landsat cloud images is easily affected by inaccurate cloud and cloud-shadow masks, and the performance of spatiotemporal data fusion highly depends on the availability of satisfactory Landsat images on the base dates.
methods: In this study, we reconstructed high-spatiotemporal-resolution NDVI time-series data (30 m and 8 days) from 2000–2020 for the QTP through the fusion of 30 m Landsat and 250 m MODIS NDVI time-series with the GF-SG method. In the first step, GF-SG fills the missing values in the original Landsat NDVI time-series data. In the second step of GF-SG, a weighted SG filter is used to smooth the synthesized NDVI time-series to reduce residual noise. We evaluated QTP-NDVI30 in three experiments. In the first experiment, we selected Landsat images obtained from July to September with cloud coverages less than 50% in 100 randomly determined subregions (30 km × 30 km) distributed relatively uniformly over the QTP. In the second experiment, 16 PlanetScope constellation multispectral images (3 m resolution) were collected at two test sites and were compared with QTP-NDVI30-based images. In the third experiment, we explored an application of QTP-NDVI30 to determine the vegetation green-up date (GUD) over the QTP.
dataset: In this study, therefore, we generated an 8-day and 30 m resolution NDVI dataset from 2000 to 2020 for the QTP through the fusion of 30 m Landsat and 250 m MODIS NDVI time-series data. This dataset, referred to as QTP-NDVI30, was reconstructed by employing all available Landsat 5/7/8 images (>100,000 scenes) and using our recently developed gap-filling and Savitzky–Golay filtering (GF-SG) method. We collected all available Landsat surface-reflectance (SR) images (red and near-infrared bands) for the QTP from 2000 to 2020, except in 2012. The collected Landsat data include those from the Landsat-5 TM (January 2000–December 2011), Landsat-7 ETM+ (January 2000-December 2020), and Landsat-8 OLI (February 2013–December 2020).
findings: We compared QTP-NDVI30 with upscaled cloud-free PlanetScope images in some topographic areas and observed consistent spatial variations in NDVI between them (averaged SSIM = 0.874). We further examined an application of QTP-NDVI30 to detect vegetation green-up dates (GUDs) and found that QTP-NDVI30-derived GUD data show general agreement in spatial patterns with the 250 m MODIS GUD data, but provide richer spatial details (e.g., GUD variations at the subpixel scale). The results show that the MAE averaged over the 100 subregions is approximately 0.02 and that the relative MAE is below 6%. The reconstructed Landsat NDVI images generally exhibit high spatial-structure similarity with the reference images, with average SSIM values above 0.94, indicating the satisfactory accuracy of the reconstructed Landsat NDVI time-series.

Disjunctive.Answer: The fusion of Landsat and MODIS data

Concept Completion.Answer: high spatial resolution requirement unmet by 250 m MODIS NDVI

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to generate a high-spatiotemporal-resolution NDVI dataset for mountainous regions?
Example.Answer: A data collection method used involves the fusion of 30 m Landsat and 250 m MODIS NDVI time-series data with the GF-SG method to reconstruct high-spatiotemporal-resolution NDVI time-series data (30 m and 8 days) from 2000–2020 for the Qinghai–Tibetan Plateau.

Example.Question: Could you give an example of how spatial resolution impacts the monitoring of vegetation dynamics in topographic regions?
Example.Answer: The impact of spatial resolution is illustrated by comparing the 250 m MODIS NDVI data with the reconstructed 30 m NDVI dataset, where the latter provides richer spatial details and allows for better monitoring of vegetation dynamics in topographic regions, as demonstrated by the consistent spatial variations observed with upscaled cloud-free PlanetScope images.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the key characteristics of datasets used for monitoring vegetation dynamics in heterogeneous topographic areas?
Feature Specification.Answer: high spatial and temporal resolution, 8-day temporal resolution, 30-meter spatial resolution, fusion of 30 m Landsat and 250 m MODIS NDVI time-series data, gap-filling, filtering

Feature Specification.Question: What features or methods are necessary for reconstructing high-quality NDVI time-series data over large and diverse geographic regions?
Feature Specification.Answer: gap-filling, Savitzky–Golay filtering, cloud removal, cloud-shadow masking

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific attributes and evaluation metrics used to assess the quality of reconstructed NDVI datasets?
Feature Specification.Answer: mean absolute error (MAE), correlation coefficients (R), structural similarity index measure (SSIM)

Quantification.Question: How many scenes of Landsat data were utilized in developing a high spatiotemporal resolution NDVI dataset for the Qinghai–Tibetan Plateau?
What is the average absolute error (MAE) of the reconstructed NDVI images in a dataset for the Qinghai–Tibetan Plateau?

Definition.Question: What is the GF-SG method in the context of NDVI time-series data reconstruction?
Definition.Answer: The GF-SG method in the context of NDVI time-series data reconstruction refers to a data fusion and filtering approach that combines Landsat and MODIS NDVI data to create a high-spatiotemporal-resolution dataset. It involves gap-filling to address missing values and the use of a weighted Savitzky–Golay (SG) filter to smooth the synthesized NDVI time-series, reducing residual noise.

Definition.Question: What are the challenges associated with reconstructing high-quality continuous Landsat NDVI time-series data?
Definition.Answer: The challenges associated with reconstructing high-quality continuous Landsat NDVI time-series data include dealing with the vast amounts of data required for analysis, cloud removal affected by inaccurate masks, and ensuring the availability of satisfactory Landsat images for spatiotemporal data fusion, especially over large areas like the Qinghai–Tibetan Plateau.

Comparison.Question: How does the data collection method using the fusion of Landsat and MODIS NDVI time-series compare to traditional NDVI data collection techniques in terms of spatial resolution and temporal frequency?
Comparison.Answer: The fusion of Landsat and MODIS NDVI time-series provides a high-spatiotemporal-resolution NDVI dataset with 30 m spatial and 8-day temporal resolution, which surpasses the traditional NDVI data collection methods like GIMMS and MODIS alone that have coarser pixel sizes (~8 km for GIMMS and 250 m for MODIS), thus improving the capability for detailed vegetation monitoring in topographic regions.

Comparison.Question: What are the challenges faced in reconstructing NDVI time-series data for large areas like the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau compared to smaller, more homogeneous areas?
Comparison.Answer: Reconstructing NDVI time-series data for large areas like the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau is challenging due to the vast amounts of Landsat imagery required, cloud removal issues affected by inaccurate cloud-shadow masks, and dependency on the availability of satisfactory Landsat images. These challenges are less pronounced in smaller, more homogeneous areas where data volume is lower and cloud coverage might be less variable.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might researchers face when attempting to improve the spatial resolution of vegetation monitoring datasets?
Interpretation.Answer: Researchers may face several challenges, such as the vast amounts of imagery required, cloud removal difficulties due to inaccurate cloud masks, and the dependency of spatiotemporal data fusion on the availability of high-quality base date images. Additionally, the need to process large datasets for extensive regions like the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau adds to the complexity.

Interpretation.Question: How might the integration of different satellite data sources contribute to the advancement of NDVI datasets over large ecological regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Integration of different satellite data sources, such as combining Landsat and MODIS NDVI time-series, enhances the spatial and temporal resolution of NDVI datasets. This approach allows for more detailed monitoring of vegetation dynamics, capturing finer spatial details and variations in vegetation indices which are beneficial for large and ecologically diverse regions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes challenges in reconstructing high-quality NDVI time-series data for large areas like the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Reconstructing high-quality NDVI time-series data for large areas like the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau presents challenges due to the vast amounts of Landsat imagery and data required for analyses. This is further complicated by issues such as cloud removal on Landsat cloud images, which can be affected by inaccurate cloud and cloud-shadow masks, and the dependency of spatiotemporal data fusion performance on the availability of satisfactory Landsat images on the base dates.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is the highest spatial resolution of MODIS NDVI products insufficient for vegetation monitoring in topographic regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The highest spatial resolution of only 250 m for MODIS NDVI products is insufficient for vegetation monitoring in topographic regions because such coarse pixel sizes impede the ability to monitor vegetation dynamics effectively in heterogeneous topographic areas, where finer spatial details are crucial for accurate analysis.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the reasons for employing data fusion techniques in generating high-resolution NDVI datasets?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Data fusion techniques are employed in generating high-resolution NDVI datasets to address the limitations of individual satellite data sources. In the case of the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau, the fusion of 30 m Landsat and 250 m MODIS NDVI time-series data helps reconstruct high-spatiotemporal-resolution NDVI datasets, overcoming the challenge of coarse pixel sizes and enabling detailed vegetation monitoring.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects on vegetation monitoring accuracy when combining high-resolution Landsat data with coarser MODIS data?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Combining high-resolution Landsat data with coarser MODIS data can improve vegetation monitoring accuracy by providing a higher spatiotemporal resolution NDVI dataset. This fusion overcomes the limitations of MODIS's 250 m spatial resolution, allowing for more detailed monitoring in heterogeneous topographic areas and capturing finer spatial variations in NDVI.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of using a high-spatial-resolution NDVI dataset on the analysis of vegetation phenological changes?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a high-spatial-resolution NDVI dataset allows for more detailed analysis of vegetation phenological changes, such as green-up dates. It provides richer spatial details, enabling the detection of variations at subpixel scales, which can offer insights into local environmental changes and improve the understanding of ecosystem processes on the Qinghai–Tibetan Plateau.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives of generating a high-spatiotemporal-resolution NDVI dataset from the fusion of Landsat and MODIS NDVI time-series data?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to create an 8-day and 30 m resolution NDVI dataset for the Qinghai–Tibetan Plateau through the fusion of 30 m Landsat and 250 m MODIS NDVI time-series data to address the limitations of existing datasets in monitoring vegetation dynamics in topographically complex regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to address the challenges of cloud removal and data availability in NDVI reconstruction for large areas?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Addressing these challenges is crucial because cloud removal on Landsat images is affected by inaccurate cloud and cloud-shadow masks, and the performance of spatiotemporal data fusion highly depends on the availability of satisfactory Landsat images, especially for vast areas like the Qinghai–Tibetan Plateau, which requires continuous high-quality NDVI time-series data.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods can be employed to reconstruct high-spatiotemporal-resolution NDVI time-series data for a large and complex region like the Qinghai–Tibetan Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To reconstruct high-spatiotemporal-resolution NDVI time-series data for a large region like the Qinghai–Tibetan Plateau, one can use the GF-SG method, which involves the fusion of Landsat and MODIS NDVI time-series data. The process includes filling missing values in the original Landsat NDVI data and applying a weighted Savitzky–Golay filter to smooth the NDVI time-series, reducing residual noise.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How do researchers address the challenges of cloud cover in Landsat imagery when reconstructing NDVI data over expansive areas?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Researchers address the challenges of cloud cover in Landsat imagery by carefully selecting images with less than 50% cloud coverage for analysis and using the GF-SG method to fill gaps and smooth the data. This method helps mitigate the issues caused by cloud cover and ensures the production of high-quality continuous NDVI time-series data.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used to evaluate the accuracy and effectiveness of reconstructed NDVI datasets in comparison with existing high-resolution satellite imagery?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To evaluate reconstructed NDVI datasets, researchers conduct experiments comparing the datasets with high-resolution images, such as PlanetScope multispectral images. They assess spatial variations, calculate structural similarity indexes, and analyze the consistency of spatial patterns, ensuring that the reconstructed datasets provide accurate and detailed representations of vegetation dynamics.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the reconstruction of high-spatiotemporal-resolution NDVI time-series data for large and heterogeneous topographic areas?
Enablement.Answer: The reconstruction of high-spatiotemporal-resolution NDVI time-series data is enabled by the fusion of 30 m Landsat and 250 m MODIS NDVI time-series data using the GF-SG method. This involves filling missing values in the original Landsat NDVI time-series and using a weighted SG filter to smooth the synthesized series, reducing residual noise.

Enablement.Question: How do advancements in data fusion techniques enhance the accuracy and spatial detail of vegetation monitoring datasets?
Enablement.Answer: Advancements in data fusion techniques, such as the GF-SG method, enhance accuracy and spatial detail by reconstructing NDVI time-series with improved spatial resolutions (30 m and 8 days) and reduced noise. The resulting datasets can offer richer spatial details and higher structure similarity with reference images, as indicated by high SSIM values.

Enablement.Question: What resources are essential for collecting and processing vast amounts of satellite imagery to generate comprehensive NDVI datasets over extensive regions?
Enablement.Answer: Essential resources include access to all available Landsat surface-reflectance images from multiple Landsat missions and the application of sophisticated gap-filling and filtering algorithms. Collecting over 100,000 Landsat scenes and employing methods like GF-SG are crucial for processing and generating high-quality NDVI datasets over extensive regions like the Qinghai–Tibetan Plateau.

Expectation.Question: Why might a high-spatial-resolution NDVI dataset encounter challenges in maintaining data continuity over expansive topographical regions?
Expectation.Answer: In large areas like the Qinghai–Tibetan Plateau, reconstructing high-quality continuous NDVI time-series data is challenging due to the vast amounts of Landsat imagery required. The performance of spatiotemporal data fusion heavily depends on the availability of satisfactory Landsat images on the base dates, and cloud removal on Landsat images can be affected by inaccurate cloud and cloud-shadow masks.

Expectation.Question: Why might reconstructing NDVI datasets for vegetation monitoring require innovative data collection methods beyond traditional approaches?
Expectation.Answer: Traditional methods may not handle the vast amounts of data or provide the spatial detail needed for expansive and topographically diverse areas like the Qinghai–Tibetan Plateau. Innovative methods, such as the GF-SG algorithm, are necessary to fill missing values and reduce residual noise, enhancing the accuracy of NDVI datasets for effective vegetation monitoring.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the main challenges associated with collecting Landsat imagery for large-scale NDVI reconstruction and how might these be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: The main challenges include handling vast amounts of Landsat imagery and the need for effective cloud and cloud-shadow removal. Addressing these challenges requires improved data fusion techniques and availability of sufficient quality Landsat images, which the GF-SG method partially resolves by filling missing values and smoothing time-series data.

Judgmental.Question: What are your thoughts on the potential of integrating higher spatial resolution data, such as PlanetScope, to enhance the accuracy and detail of NDVI datasets?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating higher spatial resolution data like PlanetScope could significantly enhance the accuracy and detail of NDVI datasets, as evidenced by the consistent spatial variations observed in the comparison with QTP-NDVI30. This integration could provide richer spatial details and improve monitoring capabilities, especially in complex topographic areas.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how a data collection method can ensure high spatial resolution for vegetation monitoring in topographic regions.
Assertion.Answer: The method involves fusing 30 m Landsat and 250 m MODIS NDVI time-series data using the GF-SG method, which fills missing values and smooths the data to reduce noise, enabling high spatial resolution for vegetation monitoring.
